sub_topic: Using the product rule to differentiate functions
message_1: Find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^2 ln(x).
message_2:
To find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^2 ln(x), we will use the product rule. The product rule states that the derivative of a product of two functions is the derivative of the first function times the second function plus the first function times the derivative of the second function. In this case, our two functions are u(x) = x^2 and v(x) = ln(x).

First, we find the derivatives of u(x) and v(x):
u'(x) = d(x^2)/dx = 2x
v'(x) = d(ln(x))/dx = 1/x

Now, we apply the product rule:
f'(x) = u'(x)v(x) + u(x)v'(x)
f'(x) = (2x)(ln(x)) + (x^2)(1/x)
f'(x) = 2xln(x) + x

So, the derivative of the function f(x) = x^2 ln(x) is f'(x) = 2xln(x) + x.
